fr:title.text: Para construction

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The term "parameters construction" or "para construction" is used for several related constructions of categories of parametrised morphisms.
For a category \mathcal C, a para construction over it will be referred to as \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P} (\mathcal C), possibly with subscripts for other data used in the construction.
Sometimes we think of these as 1-categories, they are better thought of as double categories.

fr:title.text: Para construction, naively

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a monoidal category. For objects X, Y of \mathcal C, a parametrised morphism f : X \to Y in \mathcal C consists of:

html:ul.html:li: An object M of \mathcal C called the parameter object
A morphism f : X \otimes M \to Y of \mathcal C

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There is a category \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P} (\mathcal C) where:

html:ul.html:li: Objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P} (\mathcal C) are objects of \mathcal C

Morphisms X \to Y of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P} (\mathcal C) are equivalence classes of parametrised morphisms X \to Y in \mathcal C modulo coherent isomorphisms of the objects M
The identity morphism on X is given by the parameter object I and the canonical isomorphism X \otimes I \to X
Composition of X \otimes M_1 \to Y and Y \otimes M_2 \to Z is given by the parameter object M_1 \otimes M_2 and the morphism X \otimes (M_1 \otimes M_2) \to (X \otimes M_1) \otimes M_2 \to Y \otimes M_2 \to Z

fr:mainmatter.html:p: However, in practice it is better to define this category as a quotient of a double category, and in greater generality.

fr:title.text: Locally graded categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a monoidal category. A category locally graded in \mathcal E is a category enriched in the monoidal category of presheaves [\mathcal E^\mathrm {op}, \mathbf {Set}] with Day convolution.
Unwinding the definition, a category \mathcal C locally graded in \mathcal E is given by the following data:

html:ul.html:li: A class of objects
For each pair of objects X, Y of \mathcal C and each object M of \mathcal E, a set of morphisms #\mathcal C (X, Y) (M), which we also write \mathcal C_M (X, Y)
For each object X of \mathcal C, an identity morphism in \mathcal C_I (X, X)
For morphisms f : \mathcal C_{M_1} (X, Y) and g : \mathcal C_{M_2} (Y, Z), a composite morphism fg : \mathcal C_{M_1 \otimes M_2} (X, Z)
Coherence isomorphisms

fr:title.text: From actegories to locally graded categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: From actegories to locally graded categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a monoidal category and \mathcal C an \mathcal E-actegory. We construct a locally graded category called \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C), which we regard as a Para construction, as follows:

html:ul.html:li: The objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C) are objects of \mathcal C

For objects X, Y of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C), the hom-object \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C) (X, Y) : \mathcal E^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Set} is given by \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_M (X, Y) = \mathcal C (X \bullet M, Y)
The identity morphism in \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_I (X, X) is given by the unitor X \bullet I \to X

The composition of f : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_1} (X, Y) and g : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_2} (Y, Z) is fg : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_1 \otimes M_2} (X, Z) given by X \bullet (M_1 \otimes M_2) \to (X \bullet M_1) \bullet M_2 \to Y \bullet M_2 \to Z

fr:title.text: The history functor for cartesian colinks

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The history functor for cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products and let \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) be the category of cartesian colinks.
We define the history functor \mathbb H : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) \to \mathbf {Set} to be the covariant functor represented by the tensor unit I = \binom {1}{1}.
Concretely, on objects \mathbb H is given by \mathbb H \binom {X'}{X} = \mathcal C (1, X).

\mathbb H factors through the forwards fibration via the functor \mathcal C (1, -) : \mathcal C \to \mathbf {Set}. For simple colinks in the category of sets, the history functor and the forwards fibration coincide.
The dual of the history functor is the continuation functor.

fr:title.text: The continuation functor for cartesian colinks

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The continuation functor for cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) be the category of cartesian colinks.

We define the continuation functor \mathbb K : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C)^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Set} as the contravariant functor represesented by the tensor unit I = \binom {1}{1}.
Concretely, \mathbb K is given as follows:

html:ul.html:li: On objects, \mathbb K \binom {X'}{X} = \mathcal C (X, X')

Given a cartesian colink f with forwards pass f : X \to Y and backwards pass f' : X \times Y' \to X', the function \mathbb K (f) : \mathcal C (Y, Y') \to \mathcal C (X, X') takes a morphism k : Y \to Y' to the composite
X \overset \Delta \longrightarrow X \times X \overset {X \times f}\longrightarrow X \times Y \overset {X \times k}\longrightarrow X \times Y' \overset {f'}\longrightarrow X'

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We use the term continuation to refer to a morphism X \to X' of \mathcal C when regarded as an element of \mathbb K \binom {X'}{X}.
The dual of the continuation functor is the history functor.

fr:title.text: The forwards fibration for cartesian colinks

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The forwards fibration for cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) be the category of cartesian colinks.
Concretely, \mathbb F is given as follows:

html:ul.html:li: On objects, \mathbb F \binom {X'}{X} = X
On morphisms, \mathbb F takes each cartesian colink to its forwards pass

Given an object \binom {Y'}{Y} of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) and a morphism f : X \to Y of \mathcal C, the cartesian lifting f^* \binom {Y'}{Y} : \binom {Y'}{X} \to \binom {Y}{Y'} is the colink with forwards pass f and backwards pass the projection X \times Y' \to Y'

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The forwards fibration is closely related to the history functor. They coincide for simple colinks in the category of sets.

fr:title.text: Tensor product of cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Recall the construction of the category of cartesian colinks from the indexed category of simple slices,
\overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) = \int _{X : \mathcal C} \mathcal C [X]^\mathrm {op}

Recall that the simple slice categories \mathcal C [X] have finite products given by products in \mathcal C, and that reindexing preserves them. Therefore the opposite categories \mathcal C [X]^\mathrm {op} have finite coproducts given by products in \mathcal C, and reindexing preserves them.
This structure defines a symmetric monoidal product in \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C), called the tensor product. In general the tensor product is neither cartesian nor cocartesian.
Reference: Shulman, Framed bicategories and monoidal fibrations

Concretely, on objects the tensor product is given by pairwise monoidal product:
\binom {X'}{X} \otimes \binom {Y'}{Y} = \binom {X' \times Y'}{X \times Y}
The monoidal unit is denoted I = \binom {1}{1}, where 1 is the terminal object of \mathcal C.
The tensor product of cartesian colinks is fibrewise dual to the cartesian product of cartesian links.

fr:title.text: Construction of cartesian colinks from simple slices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Construction of cartesian colinks from simple slices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let \mathcal C [-] : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat} be the indexed category of simple slices.

We define the category of cartesian colinks \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) as the total category of the opposite indexed category:
\overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) = \int _{X : \mathcal C} \mathcal C [X]^\mathrm {op}

Notice that since the simple slice categories \mathcal C [X] all have the same class of objects, namely the objects of \mathcal C, an object of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) is a pair \binom {X'}{X} of objects of \mathcal C.

fr:title.text: Simple slices as polynomial categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products and X an object of \mathcal C. Recall that the simple slice category \mathcal C [X] has finite products.
We can universally characterise \mathcal C as the smallest category with finite products that contains \mathcal C and another morphism x : 1 \to X.
Based on the analogous construction of polynomial rings, the simple slice \mathcal C [X] is sometimes called a polynomial category. This is the origin of its notation.
Reference: Lambek & Scott, Introduction to higher-order categorical logic

fr:title.text: Products in the simple slice category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Products in the simple slice category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X be an object of \mathcal C. Then the simple slice category \mathcal C [X] has finite products, given by the underlying products in \mathcal C.
To prove this, we construct the Kleisli adjunction between \mathcal C and \mathcal C [X].
The left adjoint L : \mathcal C [X] \to \mathcal C is given by:

html:ul.html:li: On objects, L (Y) = X \times Y
f : X \times Y \to Z is taken to L (f) : X \times Y \to X \times Z given by the pairing of the projection and f

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The right adjoint R : \mathcal C \to \mathcal C [X] is given by:

html:ul.html:li: R is identity on objects
f : Y \to Z is taken to R (f) : X \times Y \to Z given by precomposition with the projection

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
The hom-set isomorphism is proven as follows:
\mathcal C (L (Y), Z) = \mathcal C (X \times Y, Z) = \mathcal C [X] (Y, Z) = \mathcal C [X] (Y, R (Z))

Since R is a right adjoint it preserves limits. Since \mathcal C [X] has the same objects as \mathcal C and since R is identity on objects, this establishes that \mathcal C [X] has finite products given by finite products in \mathcal C.

X \times Y \overset {f \times Y}\longrightarrow X' \times Y \overset {g}\longrightarrow Z

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This yields an indexed category \mathcal C [-] : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat}.

This structure can also be seen as arising from the comonad morphisms f_* : \mathbb P_X \to \mathbb P_Y between the parameters comonads, since morphisms of comonads lift contravariantly to functors between Kleisli categories.
Since f^* is identity on objects, it also preserves products in simple slice categories. Thus \mathcal C [-] : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat} has indexed finite products.

fr:title.text: The parameters comonad

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X be an object of \mathcal C. The functor \mathbb P_X : \mathcal C \to \mathcal C given by \mathbb P_X (Y) = X \times Y can be given the structure of a commutative comonad, called the parameters comonad, as follows:

html:ul.html:li: The counit \mathbb P_X (Y) = X \times Y \to Y is given by the projection
The comultiplication \mathbb P_X (Y) = X \times Y \to X \times X \times Y = \mathbb P_X^2 (Y) is given by the diagonal
The commutative strength \mathbb P_X (Y) \times Z = (X \times Y) \times Z \to X \times (Y \times Z) = \mathbb P_X (Y \times Z) is the natural isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Given a morphism X \to X' of \mathcal C, the natural transformation f \times : X \times - \to X' \times - extends to a morphism of comonads f_* : \mathbb P_X \to \mathbb P_Y.

fr:mainmatter.html:p:

A costrong profunctor or Tambara comodule F : \mathcal C \to \mathcal D is a functor F : \mathcal C \times \mathcal D^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Set} equipped with a natural transformation called the costrength,
/ M : F (X \bullet M, Y \bullet M) \to F (X, Y)
The dual concept of costrong profunctors is strong profunctors.

fr:title.text: Strong profunctors

fr:mainmatter.html:p:

A strong profunctor or Tambara module F : \mathcal C \to \mathcal D is a functor F : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \times \mathcal D \to \mathbf {Set} equipped with a natural transformation called the strength,
\bullet M : F (X, Y) \to F (X \bullet M, Y \bullet M)
The dual of strong profunctors is costrong profunctors.

fr:title.text: Simple colinks in the category of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple colinks in the category of sets

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X, X', Y, Y' be sets. A simple colink f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} is given by:

html:ul.html:li: A function f : X \to Y called the forwards pass
A function f' : X \times Y' \to X' called the backwards pass

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Simple colinks are so-called to distinguish them from indexed colinks, which also exist in the category of sets.

Given simple colinks f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} and g : \binom {Y'}{Y} \to \binom {Z'}{Z}, there is a compsite colink fg : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Z'}{Z} whose forwards pass is the composite function (fg) (x) = g (f (x)) and whose backwards pass is the function (fg)' : X \times Z' \to X' defined by the colink composition law
(fg)' (x, z') = f' (x, g' (f (x), z'))

In this case we can directly prove that colink composition is associative as follows:
((fg)h)' (x, w') = (fg)' (x, h' ((fg) (x), w'))
= f' (x, g' (f (x), h' (g (f (x)), w')))
= f' (x, (gh)' (f (x), w')) = (f(gh))' (x, w')

Since the category of sets is cartesian closed, the category of colinks in the category of sets can be constructed either as a category of cartesian colinks or as a category of colinks in a monoidal closed category.

fr:title.text: Cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X, X', Y, Y' be objects of \mathcal C. A cartesian colink f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} is given by:

html:ul.html:li: A morphism f : X \to Y called the forwards pass
A morphism f' : X \times Y' \to X' called the backwards pass

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Given colinks f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} and g : \binom {Y'}{Y} \to \binom {Z'}{Z}, there is a composite colink fg : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Z'}{Z} whose forwards pass is the composite morphism fg : X \to Z and whose backwards pass (fg)' is the composite
X \times Z' \overset {\Delta _X \times Z'}\longrightarrow X \times X \times Z' \overset {X \times f \times Z'}\longrightarrow X \times Y \times Z' \overset {X \times g'}\longrightarrow X \times Y' \overset {f'}\longrightarrow X'
It is not obvious from this definition that colink composition is associative. A direct proof is possible but tedious, so we prefer to prove it using machinery of fibred categories.
For a category \mathcal C with finite products, there is a category \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) where:

html:ul.html:li: Objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) are pairs of objects of \mathcal C, written \binom {X'}{X}
Morphisms \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) are colinks \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} in \mathcal C
The identity morphism \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {X'}{X} has as forwards pass the identity morphism X \to X in \mathcal C, and as backwards pass the projection X \times X' \to X'
Composite morphisms are given by colink composition

The tensor product of cartesian colinks is fibrewise dual to the cartesian product of cartesian links.

fr:title.text: The history functor for cartesian colinks

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The history functor for cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products and let \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) be the category of cartesian colinks.
We define the history functor \mathbb H : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) \to \mathbf {Set} to be the covariant functor represented by the tensor unit I = \binom {1}{1}.
Concretely, on objects \mathbb H is given by \mathbb H \binom {X'}{X} = \mathcal C (1, X).

\mathbb H factors through the forwards fibration via the functor \mathcal C (1, -) : \mathcal C \to \mathbf {Set}. For simple colinks in the category of sets, the history functor and the forwards fibration coincide.
The dual of the history functor is the continuation functor.

fr:title.text: The continuation functor for cartesian colinks

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The continuation functor for cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) be the category of cartesian colinks.

We define the continuation functor \mathbb K : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C)^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Set} as the contravariant functor represesented by the tensor unit I = \binom {1}{1}.
Concretely, \mathbb K is given as follows:

html:ul.html:li: On objects, \mathbb K \binom {X'}{X} = \mathcal C (X, X')

Given a cartesian colink f with forwards pass f : X \to Y and backwards pass f' : X \times Y' \to X', the function \mathbb K (f) : \mathcal C (Y, Y') \to \mathcal C (X, X') takes a morphism k : Y \to Y' to the composite
X \overset \Delta \longrightarrow X \times X \overset {X \times f}\longrightarrow X \times Y \overset {X \times k}\longrightarrow X \times Y' \overset {f'}\longrightarrow X'

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We use the term continuation to refer to a morphism X \to X' of \mathcal C when regarded as an element of \mathbb K \binom {X'}{X}.
The dual of the continuation functor is the history functor.

Colinks, usually called lenses, are pairs of morphisms with the backwards morphism also having an input in the forwards direction. Composition of colinks is an abstraction of the chain rule of calculus.

There are many definitions of colinks that apply with different assumptions on the base category. In each of these cases, for a category \mathcal C with the appropriate structure we will obtain a category \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) whose morphisms are colinks in \mathcal C.

fr:title.text: Simple colinks in the category of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple colinks in the category of sets

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X, X', Y, Y' be sets. A simple colink f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} is given by:

html:ul.html:li: A function f : X \to Y called the forwards pass
A function f' : X \times Y' \to X' called the backwards pass

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Simple colinks are so-called to distinguish them from indexed colinks, which also exist in the category of sets.

Given simple colinks f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} and g : \binom {Y'}{Y} \to \binom {Z'}{Z}, there is a compsite colink fg : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Z'}{Z} whose forwards pass is the composite function (fg) (x) = g (f (x)) and whose backwards pass is the function (fg)' : X \times Z' \to X' defined by the colink composition law
(fg)' (x, z') = f' (x, g' (f (x), z'))

In this case we can directly prove that colink composition is associative as follows:
((fg)h)' (x, w') = (fg)' (x, h' ((fg) (x), w'))
= f' (x, g' (f (x), h' (g (f (x)), w')))
= f' (x, (gh)' (f (x), w')) = (f(gh))' (x, w')

Since the category of sets is cartesian closed, the category of colinks in the category of sets can be constructed either as a category of cartesian colinks or as a category of colinks in a monoidal closed category.

fr:title.text: Cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X, X', Y, Y' be objects of \mathcal C. A cartesian colink f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} is given by:

html:ul.html:li: A morphism f : X \to Y called the forwards pass
A morphism f' : X \times Y' \to X' called the backwards pass

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Given colinks f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} and g : \binom {Y'}{Y} \to \binom {Z'}{Z}, there is a composite colink fg : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Z'}{Z} whose forwards pass is the composite morphism fg : X \to Z and whose backwards pass (fg)' is the composite
X \times Z' \overset {\Delta _X \times Z'}\longrightarrow X \times X \times Z' \overset {X \times f \times Z'}\longrightarrow X \times Y \times Z' \overset {X \times g'}\longrightarrow X \times Y' \overset {f'}\longrightarrow X'
It is not obvious from this definition that colink composition is associative. A direct proof is possible but tedious, so we prefer to prove it using machinery of fibred categories.
For a category \mathcal C with finite products, there is a category \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) where:

html:ul.html:li: Objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) are pairs of objects of \mathcal C, written \binom {X'}{X}
Morphisms \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) are colinks \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} in \mathcal C
The identity morphism \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {X'}{X} has as forwards pass the identity morphism X \to X in \mathcal C, and as backwards pass the projection X \times X' \to X'
Composite morphisms are given by colink composition

fr:title.text: The simple slice category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X be an object of \mathcal C. We write \mathcal C [X] for the Kleisli category of the parameters comonad \mathbb P_X : \mathcal C \to \mathcal C.
Concretely, \mathcal C [X] is given as follows:

html:ul.html:li: Objects of \mathcal C [X] are objects of \mathcal C
Morphisms f : Y \to Z in \mathcal C [X] are morphisms f : X \times Y \to Z in \mathcal C
The identity morphism Y \to Y in \mathcal C [X] is the projection X \times Y \to Y in \mathcal C

The composition of f : X \times Y \to Z and g : X \times Z \to W is given by
X \times Y \overset \Delta \longrightarrow X \times X \times Y \overset {X \times f}\longrightarrow X \times Z \overset {g}\longrightarrow W

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Reference: Categorical logic and type theory

fr:title.text: Products in the simple slice category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Products in the simple slice category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X be an object of \mathcal C. Then the simple slice category \mathcal C [X] has finite products, given by the underlying products in \mathcal C.
To prove this, we construct the Kleisli adjunction between \mathcal C and \mathcal C [X].
The left adjoint L : \mathcal C [X] \to \mathcal C is given by:

html:ul.html:li: On objects, L (Y) = X \times Y
f : X \times Y \to Z is taken to L (f) : X \times Y \to X \times Z given by the pairing of the projection and f

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The right adjoint R : \mathcal C \to \mathcal C [X] is given by:

html:ul.html:li: R is identity on objects
f : Y \to Z is taken to R (f) : X \times Y \to Z given by precomposition with the projection

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
The hom-set isomorphism is proven as follows:
\mathcal C (L (Y), Z) = \mathcal C (X \times Y, Z) = \mathcal C [X] (Y, Z) = \mathcal C [X] (Y, R (Z))

Since R is a right adjoint it preserves limits. Since \mathcal C [X] has the same objects as \mathcal C and since R is identity on objects, this establishes that \mathcal C [X] has finite products given by finite products in \mathcal C.

fr:title.text: Simple slices as polynomial categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products and X an object of \mathcal C. Recall that the simple slice category \mathcal C [X] has finite products.
We can universally characterise \mathcal C as the smallest category with finite products that contains \mathcal C and another morphism x : 1 \to X.
Based on the analogous construction of polynomial rings, the simple slice \mathcal C [X] is sometimes called a polynomial category. This is the origin of its notation.
Reference: Lambek & Scott, Introduction to higher-order categorical logic

fr:title.text: Indexed category structure of simple slices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Indexed category structure of simple slices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products. A morphism f : X \to X' of \mathcal C induces a functor f^* : \mathcal C [X'] \to \mathcal C [X] where:

html:ul.html:li: f^* is identity on objects

For a morphism g : X' \times Y \to Z, f^* (g) : X \times Y \to Z is given by
X \times Y \overset {f \times Y}\longrightarrow X' \times Y \overset {g}\longrightarrow Z

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This yields an indexed category \mathcal C [-] : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat}.

This structure can also be seen as arising from the comonad morphisms f_* : \mathbb P_X \to \mathbb P_Y between the parameters comonads, since morphisms of comonads lift contravariantly to functors between Kleisli categories.
Since f^* is identity on objects, it also preserves products in simple slice categories. Thus \mathcal C [-] : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat} has indexed finite products.

fr:title.text: Construction of cartesian colinks from simple slices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Construction of cartesian colinks from simple slices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let \mathcal C [-] : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat} be the indexed category of simple slices.

We define the category of cartesian colinks \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) as the total category of the opposite indexed category:
\overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) = \int _{X : \mathcal C} \mathcal C [X]^\mathrm {op}

Notice that since the simple slice categories \mathcal C [X] all have the same class of objects, namely the objects of \mathcal C, an object of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) is a pair \binom {X'}{X} of objects of \mathcal C.

fr:title.text: The forwards fibration for cartesian colinks

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The forwards fibration for cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) be the category of cartesian colinks.
Concretely, \mathbb F is given as follows:

html:ul.html:li: On objects, \mathbb F \binom {X'}{X} = X
On morphisms, \mathbb F takes each cartesian colink to its forwards pass

Given an object \binom {Y'}{Y} of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) and a morphism f : X \to Y of \mathcal C, the cartesian lifting f^* \binom {Y'}{Y} : \binom {Y'}{X} \to \binom {Y}{Y'} is the colink with forwards pass f and backwards pass the projection X \times Y' \to Y'

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The forwards fibration is closely related to the history functor. They coincide for simple colinks in the category of sets.

fr:title.text: Tensor product of cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Recall the construction of the category of cartesian colinks from the indexed category of simple slices,
\overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) = \int _{X : \mathcal C} \mathcal C [X]^\mathrm {op}

Recall that the simple slice categories \mathcal C [X] have finite products given by products in \mathcal C, and that reindexing preserves them. Therefore the opposite categories \mathcal C [X]^\mathrm {op} have finite coproducts given by products in \mathcal C, and reindexing preserves them.
This structure defines a symmetric monoidal product in \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C), called the tensor product. In general the tensor product is neither cartesian nor cocartesian.
Reference: Shulman, Framed bicategories and monoidal fibrations

Concretely, on objects the tensor product is given by pairwise monoidal product:
\binom {X'}{X} \otimes \binom {Y'}{Y} = \binom {X' \times Y'}{X \times Y}
The monoidal unit is denoted I = \binom {1}{1}, where 1 is the terminal object of \mathcal C.
The tensor product of cartesian colinks is fibrewise dual to the cartesian product of cartesian links.

fr:title.text: From actegories to locally graded categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: From actegories to locally graded categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a monoidal category and \mathcal C an \mathcal E-actegory. We construct a locally graded category called \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C), which we regard as a Para construction, as follows:

html:ul.html:li: The objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C) are objects of \mathcal C

For objects X, Y of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C), the hom-object \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C) (X, Y) : \mathcal E^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Set} is given by \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_M (X, Y) = \mathcal C (X \bullet M, Y)
The identity morphism in \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_I (X, X) is given by the unitor X \bullet I \to X

The composition of f : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_1} (X, Y) and g : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_2} (Y, Z) is fg : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_1 \otimes M_2} (X, Z) given by X \bullet (M_1 \otimes M_2) \to (X \bullet M_1) \bullet M_2 \to Y \bullet M_2 \to Z

fr:title.text: The golden theorem of actegories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a symmetric monoidal category. Every \mathcal E-actegory that is also a symmetric monoidal category in a compatible way is necessarily defined by a strong symmetric monoidal functor \mathcal E \to \mathcal C, up to natural isomorphism.

Specifically, if \bullet : \mathcal C \times \mathcal E \to \mathcal C is a symmetric monoidal actegory then X \bullet M \cong X \otimes F (M) where F : \mathcal E \to \mathcal C is defined by F (M) = I \bullet M.
This means that in the vast majority of cases, actegories are redundant and strong symmetric monoidal functors suffice.
Reference: Actegories for the working amthematician, section 5

fr:title.text: Locally graded categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a monoidal category. A category locally graded in \mathcal E is a category enriched in the monoidal category of presheaves [\mathcal E^\mathrm {op}, \mathbf {Set}] with Day convolution.
Unwinding the definition, a category \mathcal C locally graded in \mathcal E is given by the following data:

html:ul.html:li: A class of objects
For each pair of objects X, Y of \mathcal C and each object M of \mathcal E, a set of morphisms #\mathcal C (X, Y) (M), which we also write \mathcal C_M (X, Y)
For each object X of \mathcal C, an identity morphism in \mathcal C_I (X, X)
For morphisms f : \mathcal C_{M_1} (X, Y) and g : \mathcal C_{M_2} (Y, Z), a composite morphism fg : \mathcal C_{M_1 \otimes M_2} (X, Z)
Coherence isomorphisms

fr:title.text: Para construction

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The term "parameters construction" or "para construction" is used for several related constructions of categories of parametrised morphisms.
For a category \mathcal C, a para construction over it will be referred to as \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P} (\mathcal C), possibly with subscripts for other data used in the construction.
Sometimes we think of these as 1-categories, they are better thought of as double categories.

fr:title.text: Para construction, naively

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a monoidal category. For objects X, Y of \mathcal C, a parametrised morphism f : X \to Y in \mathcal C consists of:

html:ul.html:li: An object M of \mathcal C called the parameter object
A morphism f : X \otimes M \to Y of \mathcal C

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There is a category \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P} (\mathcal C) where:

html:ul.html:li: Objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P} (\mathcal C) are objects of \mathcal C

Morphisms X \to Y of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P} (\mathcal C) are equivalence classes of parametrised morphisms X \to Y in \mathcal C modulo coherent isomorphisms of the objects M
The identity morphism on X is given by the parameter object I and the canonical isomorphism X \otimes I \to X
Composition of X \otimes M_1 \to Y and Y \otimes M_2 \to Z is given by the parameter object M_1 \otimes M_2 and the morphism X \otimes (M_1 \otimes M_2) \to (X \otimes M_1) \otimes M_2 \to Y \otimes M_2 \to Z

fr:mainmatter.html:p: However, in practice it is better to define this category as a quotient of a double category, and in greater generality.

fr:title.text: Locally graded categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a monoidal category. A category locally graded in \mathcal E is a category enriched in the monoidal category of presheaves [\mathcal E^\mathrm {op}, \mathbf {Set}] with Day convolution.
Unwinding the definition, a category \mathcal C locally graded in \mathcal E is given by the following data:

html:ul.html:li: A class of objects
For each pair of objects X, Y of \mathcal C and each object M of \mathcal E, a set of morphisms #\mathcal C (X, Y) (M), which we also write \mathcal C_M (X, Y)
For each object X of \mathcal C, an identity morphism in \mathcal C_I (X, X)
For morphisms f : \mathcal C_{M_1} (X, Y) and g : \mathcal C_{M_2} (Y, Z), a composite morphism fg : \mathcal C_{M_1 \otimes M_2} (X, Z)
Coherence isomorphisms

fr:title.text: From actegories to locally graded categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: From actegories to locally graded categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a monoidal category and \mathcal C an \mathcal E-actegory. We construct a locally graded category called \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C), which we regard as a Para construction, as follows:

html:ul.html:li: The objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C) are objects of \mathcal C

For objects X, Y of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C), the hom-object \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C) (X, Y) : \mathcal E^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Set} is given by \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_M (X, Y) = \mathcal C (X \bullet M, Y)
The identity morphism in \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_I (X, X) is given by the unitor X \bullet I \to X

The composition of f : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_1} (X, Y) and g : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_2} (Y, Z) is fg : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_1 \otimes M_2} (X, Z) given by X \bullet (M_1 \otimes M_2) \to (X \bullet M_1) \bullet M_2 \to Y \bullet M_2 \to Z

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Colinks, usually called lenses, are pairs of morphisms with the backwards morphism also having an input in the forwards direction. Composition of colinks is an abstraction of the chain rule of calculus.

There are many definitions of colinks that apply with different assumptions on the base category. In each of these cases, for a category \mathcal C with the appropriate structure we will obtain a category \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) whose morphisms are colinks in \mathcal C.

fr:title.text: Simple colinks in the category of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple colinks in the category of sets

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X, X', Y, Y' be sets. A simple colink f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} is given by:

html:ul.html:li: A function f : X \to Y called the forwards pass
A function f' : X \times Y' \to X' called the backwards pass

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Simple colinks are so-called to distinguish them from indexed colinks, which also exist in the category of sets.

Given simple colinks f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} and g : \binom {Y'}{Y} \to \binom {Z'}{Z}, there is a compsite colink fg : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Z'}{Z} whose forwards pass is the composite function (fg) (x) = g (f (x)) and whose backwards pass is the function (fg)' : X \times Z' \to X' defined by the colink composition law
(fg)' (x, z') = f' (x, g' (f (x), z'))

In this case we can directly prove that colink composition is associative as follows:
((fg)h)' (x, w') = (fg)' (x, h' ((fg) (x), w'))
= f' (x, g' (f (x), h' (g (f (x)), w')))
= f' (x, (gh)' (f (x), w')) = (f(gh))' (x, w')

Since the category of sets is cartesian closed, the category of colinks in the category of sets can be constructed either as a category of cartesian colinks or as a category of colinks in a monoidal closed category.

fr:title.text: Cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X, X', Y, Y' be objects of \mathcal C. A cartesian colink f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} is given by:

html:ul.html:li: A morphism f : X \to Y called the forwards pass
A morphism f' : X \times Y' \to X' called the backwards pass

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Given colinks f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} and g : \binom {Y'}{Y} \to \binom {Z'}{Z}, there is a composite colink fg : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Z'}{Z} whose forwards pass is the composite morphism fg : X \to Z and whose backwards pass (fg)' is the composite
X \times Z' \overset {\Delta _X \times Z'}\longrightarrow X \times X \times Z' \overset {X \times f \times Z'}\longrightarrow X \times Y \times Z' \overset {X \times g'}\longrightarrow X \times Y' \overset {f'}\longrightarrow X'
It is not obvious from this definition that colink composition is associative. A direct proof is possible but tedious, so we prefer to prove it using machinery of fibred categories.
For a category \mathcal C with finite products, there is a category \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) where:

html:ul.html:li: Objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) are pairs of objects of \mathcal C, written \binom {X'}{X}
Morphisms \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) are colinks \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} in \mathcal C
The identity morphism \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {X'}{X} has as forwards pass the identity morphism X \to X in \mathcal C, and as backwards pass the projection X \times X' \to X'
Composite morphisms are given by colink composition

fr:title.text: The simple slice category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X be an object of \mathcal C. We write \mathcal C [X] for the Kleisli category of the parameters comonad \mathbb P_X : \mathcal C \to \mathcal C.
Concretely, \mathcal C [X] is given as follows:

html:ul.html:li: Objects of \mathcal C [X] are objects of \mathcal C
Morphisms f : Y \to Z in \mathcal C [X] are morphisms f : X \times Y \to Z in \mathcal C
The identity morphism Y \to Y in \mathcal C [X] is the projection X \times Y \to Y in \mathcal C

The composition of f : X \times Y \to Z and g : X \times Z \to W is given by
X \times Y \overset \Delta \longrightarrow X \times X \times Y \overset {X \times f}\longrightarrow X \times Z \overset {g}\longrightarrow W

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Reference: Categorical logic and type theory

fr:title.text: Products in the simple slice category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Products in the simple slice category

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X be an object of \mathcal C. Then the simple slice category \mathcal C [X] has finite products, given by the underlying products in \mathcal C.
To prove this, we construct the Kleisli adjunction between \mathcal C and \mathcal C [X].
The left adjoint L : \mathcal C [X] \to \mathcal C is given by:

html:ul.html:li: On objects, L (Y) = X \times Y
f : X \times Y \to Z is taken to L (f) : X \times Y \to X \times Z given by the pairing of the projection and f

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The right adjoint R : \mathcal C \to \mathcal C [X] is given by:

html:ul.html:li: R is identity on objects
f : Y \to Z is taken to R (f) : X \times Y \to Z given by precomposition with the projection

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
The hom-set isomorphism is proven as follows:
\mathcal C (L (Y), Z) = \mathcal C (X \times Y, Z) = \mathcal C [X] (Y, Z) = \mathcal C [X] (Y, R (Z))

Since R is a right adjoint it preserves limits. Since \mathcal C [X] has the same objects as \mathcal C and since R is identity on objects, this establishes that \mathcal C [X] has finite products given by finite products in \mathcal C.

fr:title.text: Simple slices as polynomial categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products and X an object of \mathcal C. Recall that the simple slice category \mathcal C [X] has finite products.
We can universally characterise \mathcal C as the smallest category with finite products that contains \mathcal C and another morphism x : 1 \to X.
Based on the analogous construction of polynomial rings, the simple slice \mathcal C [X] is sometimes called a polynomial category. This is the origin of its notation.
Reference: Lambek & Scott, Introduction to higher-order categorical logic

fr:title.text: Indexed category structure of simple slices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Indexed category structure of simple slices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products. A morphism f : X \to X' of \mathcal C induces a functor f^* : \mathcal C [X'] \to \mathcal C [X] where:

html:ul.html:li: f^* is identity on objects

For a morphism g : X' \times Y \to Z, f^* (g) : X \times Y \to Z is given by
X \times Y \overset {f \times Y}\longrightarrow X' \times Y \overset {g}\longrightarrow Z

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This yields an indexed category \mathcal C [-] : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat}.

This structure can also be seen as arising from the comonad morphisms f_* : \mathbb P_X \to \mathbb P_Y between the parameters comonads, since morphisms of comonads lift contravariantly to functors between Kleisli categories.
Since f^* is identity on objects, it also preserves products in simple slice categories. Thus \mathcal C [-] : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat} has indexed finite products.

fr:title.text: Construction of cartesian colinks from simple slices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Construction of cartesian colinks from simple slices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let \mathcal C [-] : \mathcal C^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Cat} be the indexed category of simple slices.

We define the category of cartesian colinks \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) as the total category of the opposite indexed category:
\overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) = \int _{X : \mathcal C} \mathcal C [X]^\mathrm {op}

Notice that since the simple slice categories \mathcal C [X] all have the same class of objects, namely the objects of \mathcal C, an object of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) is a pair \binom {X'}{X} of objects of \mathcal C.

fr:title.text: The forwards fibration for cartesian colinks

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The forwards fibration for cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) be the category of cartesian colinks.
Concretely, \mathbb F is given as follows:

html:ul.html:li: On objects, \mathbb F \binom {X'}{X} = X
On morphisms, \mathbb F takes each cartesian colink to its forwards pass

Given an object \binom {Y'}{Y} of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) and a morphism f : X \to Y of \mathcal C, the cartesian lifting f^* \binom {Y'}{Y} : \binom {Y'}{X} \to \binom {Y}{Y'} is the colink with forwards pass f and backwards pass the projection X \times Y' \to Y'

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The forwards fibration is closely related to the history functor. They coincide for simple colinks in the category of sets.

fr:title.text: Tensor product of cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Recall the construction of the category of cartesian colinks from the indexed category of simple slices,
\overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) = \int _{X : \mathcal C} \mathcal C [X]^\mathrm {op}

Recall that the simple slice categories \mathcal C [X] have finite products given by products in \mathcal C, and that reindexing preserves them. Therefore the opposite categories \mathcal C [X]^\mathrm {op} have finite coproducts given by products in \mathcal C, and reindexing preserves them.
This structure defines a symmetric monoidal product in \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C), called the tensor product. In general the tensor product is neither cartesian nor cocartesian.
Reference: Shulman, Framed bicategories and monoidal fibrations

Concretely, on objects the tensor product is given by pairwise monoidal product:
\binom {X'}{X} \otimes \binom {Y'}{Y} = \binom {X' \times Y'}{X \times Y}
The monoidal unit is denoted I = \binom {1}{1}, where 1 is the terminal object of \mathcal C.
The tensor product of cartesian colinks is fibrewise dual to the cartesian product of cartesian links.

fr:title.text: The history functor for cartesian colinks

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The history functor for cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products and let \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) be the category of cartesian colinks.
We define the history functor \mathbb H : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) \to \mathbf {Set} to be the covariant functor represented by the tensor unit I = \binom {1}{1}.
Concretely, on objects \mathbb H is given by \mathbb H \binom {X'}{X} = \mathcal C (1, X).

\mathbb H factors through the forwards fibration via the functor \mathcal C (1, -) : \mathcal C \to \mathbf {Set}. For simple colinks in the category of sets, the history functor and the forwards fibration coincide.
The dual of the history functor is the continuation functor.

fr:title.text: The continuation functor for cartesian colinks

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The continuation functor for cartesian colinks

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) be the category of cartesian colinks.

We define the continuation functor \mathbb K : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C)^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Set} as the contravariant functor represesented by the tensor unit I = \binom {1}{1}.
Concretely, \mathbb K is given as follows:

html:ul.html:li: On objects, \mathbb K \binom {X'}{X} = \mathcal C (X, X')

Given a cartesian colink f with forwards pass f : X \to Y and backwards pass f' : X \times Y' \to X', the function \mathbb K (f) : \mathcal C (Y, Y') \to \mathcal C (X, X') takes a morphism k : Y \to Y' to the composite
X \overset \Delta \longrightarrow X \times X \overset {X \times f}\longrightarrow X \times Y \overset {X \times k}\longrightarrow X \times Y' \overset {f'}\longrightarrow X'

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We use the term continuation to refer to a morphism X \to X' of \mathcal C when regarded as an element of \mathbb K \binom {X'}{X}.
The dual of the continuation functor is the history functor.

fr:title.text: From actegories to locally graded categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: From actegories to locally graded categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a monoidal category and \mathcal C an \mathcal E-actegory. We construct a locally graded category called \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C), which we regard as a Para construction, as follows:

html:ul.html:li: The objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C) are objects of \mathcal C

For objects X, Y of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C), the hom-object \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C) (X, Y) : \mathcal E^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Set} is given by \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_M (X, Y) = \mathcal C (X \bullet M, Y)
The identity morphism in \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_I (X, X) is given by the unitor X \bullet I \to X

The composition of f : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_1} (X, Y) and g : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_2} (Y, Z) is fg : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_1 \otimes M_2} (X, Z) given by X \bullet (M_1 \otimes M_2) \to (X \bullet M_1) \bullet M_2 \to Y \bullet M_2 \to Z
